parts: Identify this 1981 novel in which the Smales family is forced to flee war-torn Johannesburg to live in the home village of their servant, the title character.
This female South African author of The Conservationist and Burger's Daughter wrote July's People

In the title of a 2007 short story collection, Gordimer asserted that this composer "was one-sixteenth black". Adrienne Rich described this man's most famous symphony as "yelling at Joy from the tunnel of the ego" in a poem about that work "understood at last as a sexual message".

answers: Council of the Ancients [or Council of the Elders; or Conseil des Anciens]
parts: The history of this political body is divided by the Coup of 18 Fructidor. The Constitution of Year III stipulated that it would be made up of 750 representatives
Representation in the Directory was split between the Council of Five Hundred and this other body. This body selected the five Directors
The Directory ended through the Coup of 18 Brumaire, which brought this general to power as a consul.

answers: ASEAN [or Association of Southeast Asian Nations]
parts: Name this longtime dictator and head of the New Order government who was succeeded by his vice-president BJ Habibie.
Suharto succeeded Sukarno as the leader of this island nation. East Timor gained independence from this nation in 2002.

Suharto hosted the first summit this multinational entity, which originally included Indonesia, Singapore, the Philippines, Malaysia and Thailand. It created a free-trade area using the Common Effective Preferential Tariff scheme.
Name this unusual bacterium that can survive in the stomach and is the causative agent of most gastric ulcers

H. pylori has the ability to cleave this nitrogenous compound, which is created from arginine in a namesake metabolic cycle. In humans, this is the primary molecule used to excrete nitrogen into the urine.
This hormone, which is secreted from the G cells of the stomach's antrum, is the primary driving force for the secretion of acid from parietal cells.
Identify this play, set mostly on a park bench, in which Jerry continually attempts to converse with Peter. It ends with Peter picking up a knife Jerry drops, prompting Jerry to impale himself on it.
In this play by the author of The Zoo Story, George and Martha tear down the illusions surrounding their marriage while Nick and Honey are dragged into their argument.
This absurdist American playwright wrote The Zoo Story and Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?.
Identify these errors, which alter the flow of a program's execution. In Java, they include NullPointer, NegativeArraySize, and IllegalAccess
Java supports these types of exceptions, which are defined in a function's signature. For instance, the IOException in InputStreamReader.read() is this type of exception
If a method does not handle a checked exception in Java, it must use this keyword to propagate the exception up the stack
John Maynard Keynes became a household name after publishing this 1919 book predicting the disastrous fallout of the harsh terms enforced on Germany through the Treaty of Versailles.
The denigration of economics as the "dismal science" was popularized by the debate around this man's Essay on the Principle of Population, which warned of the dangers of exponential growth

The term "dismal science" was coined in this Scottish thinker's exceptionally racist "Occasional Discourse on the Negro Question." This author of a major study on heroic leadership incorporated many of his philosophical ideas into his novel Sartor Resartus
Name this 20th century Russian composer of fifteen symphonies, including ones nicknamed "Babi Yar" and "Leningrad."

In 1937, Shostakovich responded to the accusations in "Chaos Instead of Music" by composing this D minor symphony, which became known as "a Soviet artist's creative response to justified criticism." It rehabilitated his relationship with Soviet authorities.
Shostakovich's first concerto for this instrument was dedicated to David Oistrakh, who premiered it. Modern players of this instrument include Sarah Chang, Hilary Hahn, and Itzhak Perlman.
Acts begins with Matthias being chosen in the upper room to replace this disciple of Jesus, a fellow who died shortly after he betrayed Jesus in the garden of Gethsemane.
One section in Acts tells of this deacon, who performs miracles in Samaria. Known as the evangelist, this man baptizes Simon Magus, who then later attempts to buy the power of miracles from Peter
After his stay in Samaria, Philip then meets a eunuch from this modern-day country, which was one of the first countries, along with Armenia, to adopt Christianity as a state religion.

answers: FACE CENTER CUBIC, HEXAGONAL CLOSE PACKED
parts: Crystals like sodium chloride are held together by these kinds of bonds, which are simply electrostatic interactions between species of opposite charge
There are two crystal configurations that maximize the amount of space taken up in the unit cell, with a packing factor around 74%. Name either
These phenomena are disruptions of the regularly ordered lattice structure of a crystal. Some of them are named for Schottky and Frenkel.
Name these eternal objects surrounded by void, which can rearrange to form visible physical objects. By definition, they cannot be cut or divided.
This Latin thinker repeated the claim that the random "swerve" of atoms from a straight path allows for free will in his poetic De rerum natura, or On the Nature of Things
Lucretius attributed the formation of the "swerve" theory to this atomist, who prized a serenity known as "ataraxia," taught at The Garden, and held that pleasure was the ultimate good.

Name this poet who began one work with the exhortation, "Maid of Athens, ere we part, give, oh, give, me back my heart." and wrote another poem about a figure who moves "like the night of cloudless climes and starry skies".
This last aforementioned poem was inspired by Byron's cousin Lady Anne Wilmot. It says of the title female figure that "all that/s best of dark and bright meet in her aspect and her eyes"
Lord Byron insulted Robert Southey in the preface to a satiric epic in ottava rima about this famous Spanish lover, whose first literary appearance was in Tirso di Molina's The Trickster of Seville.
] Name this African-American teenager from Florida who was walking home from a corner store when George Zimmerman shot him
This Florida governor, who defeated Alex Sink in 2010, appointed Angela Corey to be the special prosecutor in the Trayvon Martin Case.
This Fox News Channel personality asserted that Martin's "gangsta style clothing" was as culpable in the shooting as Zimmerman
Name this novel in which Nikolai Rostov enlists in General Kutuzov's army while his sister Natasha pines after Prince Andrei

This author donated the royalties from his novel Resurrection to the Doukhobors' migration effort, completing his religious self-distancing from his two largest novels, War and Peace and Anna Karenina.

This family in War and Peace includes Pierre Bezukhov's wife HÃ©lÃ¨ne and the panderer Anatole, who almost seduces Natasha at the opera. Its patriarch, Vassily, speaks in French with Anna Scherer at the novel's opening
Identify this value representing the stored energy of a system, the gravitational version of which is equal to m times g times h

For a horizontal spring at displacement x from the equilibrium point, with a spring constant of k, and a mass of m on the end, this is the potential energy of the spring-mass system. You may assume at equilibrium the PE is zero

On a potential energy surface, equilibria can be found at both maxima and minima. Equilibria that occur on maxima have this property, in which very small perturbations will push the system out of equilibrium
Name this Lord Protector, whose New Model Army perpetrated massacres at Drogheda and Wexford during his invasion of Ireland.
Charles I created this legislative body, that was purged by Cromwell's general Thomas Pride. This body abolished the Star Chamber
] Cromwell presided over these discussions about the formation of a new constitution, during which Henry Ireton opposed attempts by the Levellers to institute universal male suffrage
Identify this work of Robert Smithson completed in 1970 that was submerged for many years after its creation.
Smithson's oeuvre shares motifs with public-art projects like The Gates and Running Fence created by this woman and her husband, Christo.
Jeanne-Claude once wrapped this building in polypropylene. A famous photo by Yevgeny Khaldei sees a Soviet soldier holding a flag on top of this building.
Identify this 14-fingered, 14-toed hero of the Ulster cycle, who wielded the spear Gae Bolg and fought in the Cattle Raid of Cooley
Cu Chulainn got his name after killing one of these animals belonging to the smith Culainn. For his final labor, Heracles captured one of these animals with three heads.
Cu Chulainn spurned this goddess of death and war, who often appears as a crow. During the Cattle Raid of Cooley, she turned herself into an eel and tripped Cu Chulainn.
Identify this god of love who was commonly depicted in art rescuing Psyche with a kiss

A shoe is flung towards a statue of Cupid holding his finger to his lips in the best known painting by this artist. A prostitute holds a bouquet of flowers in his The Love Letter, and he was a contemporary of Boucher

] The Madame du Barry commissioned this series of paintings by Fragonard. A laurel wreath is held above one figure's head in The Lover Crowned, while other paintings in this series include The Surprise.
] It all began when this secretary of the Montgomery chapter of the NAACP refused to give up her seat when bus driver James F Blake asked her to.
] In the aftermath of the boycott, a group of sixty ministers formed this organization, whose first president was Martin Luther King, Jr

King's chief advisor during the formation of the SCLC was this oft-imprisoned former Communist, who was the chief organizer of the March on Washington. Congressman Adam Clayton Powell forced him to resign from the SCLC by threatening to reveal his homosexuality
Identify this novel in which the protagonist eventually marries Carl Lindstrum after the death of her brother Emil
O Pioneers was written by this American author, who wrote about Jim Burden and the Shimerda family in her novel My Antonia
In this other Cather novel, Mr. Harsanyi talks Moonstone, Colorado native Thea Kronborg into taking singing lessons with Madison Bowers, furthering her rise to become a world-famous opera singer.
Identify this small gaseous hormone which relaxes blood vessels. Viagra notably works by increasing the downstream effects of this hormone.
People with this condition often do not secrete as much nitric oxide as they should. This condition is defined as blood pressure above 140 over 90 milimeters of mercury.

Viagra works by inhibiting PDE5, which degrades this cyclic nucleotide that has a structure similar to cAMP ("c-A-M-P"). This molecule activates protein kinase G, which then activates downstream signals.
The Enola Gay dropped Little Boy on what city, the first target of an atomic bomb in history?
One of the justifications for the use of the atomic bomb was that this operation, an invasion of mainland Japan, would have cost far more casualties on both sides
Although Kyoto was originally listed as a target for the atomic bomb, this Secretary of War removed it from the list. His "doctrine" pledges non-recognition of territorial changes made by force.
